facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 797 of 1963 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 27, 1959 of the Madras High Court in C.R.P. No. 1282 of 1958.

facts.text: Madras High Court delivered judgment and order dated March 27, 1959 in C.R.P. No. 1282 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 27, 1959 of the Madras High Court in C.R.P. No. 1282 of 1958.

facts.text: On April 24, 1958, the respondent deposited Rs. 462/- as rent for 1367 fasli in the Revenue Court of the Revenue Divisional Officer, Tanjore.

anchor.surface_text: On April 24, 1958, the respondent claiming to be the cultivating tenant of the appellant in respect of certain lands in Manapparavaivattam, Nannilam Taluk deposited Rs. 462/- as rent for 1367 fasli in the Revenue Court  the Court of the Revenue Divisional Officer , Tanjore under s. 3 3  of the Madras

facts.text: The deposit was made under section 3(3) of the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955 (Madras Act No. 25 of 1955).

anchor.surface_text: deposited Rs. 462/- as rent for 1367 fasli in the Revenue Court  the Court of the Revenue Divisional Officer , Tanjore under s. 3 3  of the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955  Madras Act No. 25 of 1955  and filed an application before the Court praying for a declaration

facts.text: Respondent filed an application before the Revenue Court praying for a declaration that the amount deposited represented the correct amount of rent due from him.

anchor.surface_text: and filed an application before the Court praying for a declaration that the amount deposited represented the companyrect amount of rent due from him.

facts.text: Appellant denied that the respondent was his cultivating tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied that the respondent was his cultivating tenant.

facts.text: On July 31, 1958, the Revenue Court, Tanjore held that the respondent was not a cultivating tenant of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1958, the Revenue Court, Tanjore held that the respondent was number a cultivating tenant of the appellant and companyld number claim the benefit of s. 3 3  and dismissed the application.

facts.text: Revenue Court dismissed the respondent's application.

anchor.surface_text: and companyld number claim the benefit of s. 3 3  and dismissed the application.

facts.text: Respondent filed a petition in revision before the Madras High Court under s. 6-B of the Act read with s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a petition in revision before the Madras High Court under s. 6-B of the Act read with s. II 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed the revision petition and declared that the amount deposited represented the correct amount due from respondent to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that the respondent was a cultivating tenant of the appellant and by its order dated March 27, 1959, allowed the revision petition and declared that the amount deposited by the respondent represented the companyrect amount due from him to the appellant.

facts.text: High Court found that the respondent was a cultivating tenant of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that the respondent was a cultivating tenant of the appellant and by its order dated March 27, 1959, allowed the revision petition and declared that the amount deposited by the respondent represented the companyrect amount due from him to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant appeals to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955 came into force on September 27, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on September 27, 1955 and was amend- ed from time to time. Originally, the Act was temporary, recently .it, has been made permanent.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Revenue Divisional Officer held respondent not a cultivating tenant and declined jurisdiction under s.3(3).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Tribunal found that the respondent was number the cultivating tenant of the appellant, and on such finding declined to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it by s. 3 3  to determine the companyrect amount of rent due by the respondent to the appellant.

facts.text: High Court reviewed oral and documentary evidence and found respondent was cultivating tenant.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the entire oral and documentary evidence, the High Court found that the respondent was the cultivating tenant of the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant submitted that the finding of Revenue Court was a finding of fact not revisable by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant submitted that the finding of the Revenue Court that the respondent was number a cultivating tenant was a finding of fact and the High Court had numberjurisdiction to set it aside on revision.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent submitted that the finding was on a collateral fact affecting jurisdiction.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no reason to interfere with High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on September 27, 1955 and was amend- ed from time to time. Originally, the Act was temporary, recently .it, has been made permanent. The Act was passed for the protection of certain cultivating tenants from eviction. Section 2 defines, enter alia, cultivating tenant and landlord.

concepts.interpretation: Cultivating tenant: person who carries on personal cultivation under tenancy agreement, express or implied, continuing in possession post-determination, and heirs. Landlord: entitled to evict.

issues.text: Whether the decision of the Revenue Divisional Officer that the respondent is not a cultivating tenant of the appellant is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under sub-ss. (a) and (b) of s. 115 CPC read with s. 6-B of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question is, on which side of the line the present case lies, and whether the decision of the Revenue Divisional Officer that the respondent is number a cultivating tenant of the appellant is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction of the Revenue Divisional Officer under s. 3(3) of the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955 depends on the existence of the relationship of landlord and cultivating tenant between the parties

anchor.surface_text: To attract the jurisdiction of the Revenue Divisional officer, there must be a dispute between a landlord and cultivating tenant. The existence of the relation of landlord and cultivating tenant between the companytending parties is the essential

arguments.claim: The finding of the Revenue Court that the respondent was not a cultivating tenant was a finding of fact and the High Court had no jurisdiction to set it aside on revision.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant submitted that the finding of the Revenue Court that the respondent was not a cultivating tenant was a finding of fact and the High Court had nojurisdiction to set it aside on revision.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s the essential companydition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer- in all proceedings under the Act. The Tribunal can

arguments.court_reasoning: The finding concerns a preliminary fact essential for jurisdiction under the Act, making it revisable under s.115(a)(b) CPC read with s.6-B.

arguments.claim: The finding was in respect of a collateral fact upon the existence of which the jurisdiction of the Revenue Court under s. 3(3) depended and the High Court had ample power to revise the finding under s. 6-B of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, counsel for the respondent submitted that the finding was in respect of a collateral fact upon the existence of which the jurisdiction of the Revenue Court under s. 3(3) depended and the High Court had ample power to revise the finding under s. 6-B of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s the essential companydition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer- in all proceedings under the Act. The Tribunal can

arguments.court_reasoning: The relationship of landlord and cultivating tenant is an essential condition for jurisdiction, so the Revenue Court's decision refusing jurisdiction was erroneous and revisable.

arguments.claim: The decision of the subordinate Court on all questions of law and fact not touching its jurisdiction is final and not revisable under sub-ss. (a) and (b) of s. 115.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the subordinate Court on all questions of law and fact not touching its jurisdiction is final and however erroneous such a decision may be, it is not revisable under sub-ss. (a) and (b) of s. 115.

arguments.claim: If by an erroneous decision on a question of fact or law touching its jurisdiction, e.g., on a preliminary fact upon the existence of which its jurisdiction depends, the subordinate Court assumes or fails to exercise jurisdiction, its decision is not final and is subject to review under sub-ss. (a) and (b) of s. 115.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, if by an erroneous decision on a question of fact or law touching its jurisdiction, e.g., on a preliminary fact upon the existence of which its jurisdiction depends, the subordinate Court assumes a jurisdiction not vested in it by law or fails to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, its decision is not final, and is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under sub-ss. (a) and (b) of s. 115.

arguments.claim: The Revenue Divisional Officer is an inferior Court of limited jurisdiction functioning under the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Divisional Officer is an inferior Court of limited Jurisdiction functioning under the Madras Cultivating Tenants Protection Act, 1955. To ascertain the limit and extent of its jurisdiction, we must examine the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: The existence of the relation of landlord and cultivating tenant between the contending parties is the essential condition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer in all proceedings under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: To attract the jurisdiction of the Revenue Divisional officer, there must be a dispute between a landlord and cultivating tenant. The existence of the relation of landlord and cultivating tenant between the contending parties is the essential condition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer- in all proceedings under the Act.

arguments.claim: The Tribunal's decision on the existence of the preliminary fact of landlord-cultivating tenant relationship is not final and is subject to review by the High Court under s. 6-B, as the enquiry is summary with no appeal and legislature could not have intended finality on question of title.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal can exercise its jurisdiction under the Act only if such relationship exists. If the jurisdiction of the Tribunal is challenged, it must enquire into the existence of the preliminary fact and decide if it has jurisdiction. But its decision on the existence of this preliminary fact is not final such a decision is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 6-B.

arguments.claim: In this case, the Revenue Court erroneously refused to exercise jurisdiction under s.3(3) by finding no tenancy, which the High Court could set aside under s.115(b) read with s.6-B.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Tribunal found that the respondent was not the cultivating tenant of the appellant, and on such finding declined to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it by s. 3(3) to determine the correct amount of rent due by the respondent to the appellant.

arguments.claim: The High Court's finding on review of oral and documentary evidence that respondent was cultivating tenant is not erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the entire oral and documentary evidence, the High Court found that the respondent was the cultivating tenant of the appellant. It is not shown that this finding is erroneous.

arguments.claim: There is no reason to interfere with the High Court's decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is not shown that this finding is erroneous. We see no reason for interfering with the decision of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Respondent was not a cultivating tenant and could not claim the benefit of s. 3(3).

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1958, the Revenue Court, Tanjore held that the respondent was not a cultivating tenant of the appellant and could not claim the benefit of s. 3(3) and dismissed the application.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s the essential companydition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer- in all proceedings under the Act. The Tribunal can

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court correctly revised as it was a jurisdictional fact.

holdings.text: If by an erroneous decision on a question of fact or law touching its jurisdiction, e.g., on a preliminary fact upon the existence of which its jurisdiction depends, the subordinate Court assumes a jurisdiction not vested in it by law or fails to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, its decision is not final, and is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under sub-ss. (a) and (b) of s. 115.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, if by an erroneous decision on a question of fact or law touching its jurisdiction, e.g., on a preliminary fact upon the existence of which its jurisdiction depends, the subordinate Court assumes a jurisdiction number vested in it by law or fails to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, its decision is number final, and is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under sub-ss.  a  and  b  of s. 115.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes finality of decisions not touching jurisdiction from revisability of those affecting assumption or refusal of jurisdiction under s.115(a) and (b).

holdings.text: The existence of the relation of landlord and cultivating tenant between the contending parties is the essential condition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer in all proceedings under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: To attract the jurisdiction of the Revenue Divisional officer, there must be a dispute between a landlord and cultivating tenant. The existence of the relation of landlord and cultivating tenant between the contending parties is the essential condition for the assumption of jurisdiction by the Revenue Divisional Officer- in all proceedings under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of the Act vest jurisdiction only in disputes between landlord and cultivating tenant; examined scheme of ss.1,2,3,4,6.

holdings.text: The decision of the Tribunal on the existence of the preliminary fact of landlord-cultivating tenant relationship is not final and is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 6-B.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal can exercise its jurisdiction under the Act only if such relationship exists. If the jurisdiction of the Tribunal is challenged, it must enquire into the existence of the preliminary fact and decide if it has jurisdiction. But its decision on the existence of this preliminary fact is number final such a decision is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 6-B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summary nature of enquiry, absence of appeal, and question of title require revisional oversight by High Court under s.6-B read with s.115.

holdings.text: The High Court had power to enquire into the correctness of the Tribunal's decision that respondent was not cultivating tenant, and could set it aside under s.115(b) read with s.6-B as Tribunal erroneously refused jurisdiction under s.3(3).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Tribunal found that the respondent was number the cultivating tenant of the appellant, and on such finding declined to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it by s. 3 3  to determine the companyrect amount of rent due by the respondent to the appellant. The High Court had power to enquire into the companyrectness of this decision, and on finding that the tenancy existed and the Tribunal had erroneously refused to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it by s. 3 3 , the High Court companyld set aside the decision under .sub-s.  b  of s. 115 of the Code read with s. 6-B of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied principle of jurisdictional fact to specific refusal of jurisdiction under s.3(3) by Revenue Court.

holdings.text: On review of evidence, High Court finding that respondent was cultivating tenant of appellant is not erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the entire oral and documentary evidence, the High Court found that the respondent was the cultivating tenant of the appellant. It is number shown that this finding is erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No interference shown with High Court's evidence evaluation.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, if by an erroneous decision on a question of fact or law touching its jurisdiction, e.g., on a preliminary fact upon the existence of which its jurisdiction depends, the subordinate Court assumes a jurisdiction number vested in it by law or fails to exercise a jurisdiction so vested, its decision is number final, and is subject to review by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under sub-ss.  a  and  b  of s. 115.

anchor.surface_text: To attract the jurisdiction of the Revenue Divisional officer, there must be a dispute between a landlord and cultivating tenant. anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Tribunal found that the respondent was number the cultivating tenant of the appellant, and on such finding declined to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it by s. 3 3  to determine the companyrect amount of rent due by the respondent to the appellant. The High Court had power to enquire into the companyrectness of this decision, and on finding that the tenancy existed and the Tribunal had erroneously refused to exercise the jurisdiction vested in it by s. 3 3 , the High Court companyld set aside the decision under .sub-s.  b  of s. 115 of the Code read with s. 6-B of the Act.
